title-group.article-title: Heat Stroke in an Infant With Hypohidrotic Ectodermal Dysplasia
title-group.subtitle: Brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging Findings

abstract.p: We describe the magnetic resonance imaging findings of a 4 month old infant with hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia who developed heat stroke. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed signal alteration with restricted diffusion in the splenium of corpus callosum, cerebral peduncles and cerebellar dentate nuclei.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 4-month-old boy presented with high grade fever and seizures for 2 days. He had had 3 similar episodes in the past, starting at 6 weeks of age. During these episodes, he developed very high grade fever, documented up to 106°F. During the peak of fever, he had multiple episodes of seizures, with stiffening of all 4 limbs and uprolling of eyeballs. Investigations for sepsis and meningitis during these episodes were normal. He improved with supportive measures (intravenous fluids, cooling, paracetamol, and antibiotics) within 48 to 72 hours. He was well between the episodes. He was the first child of nonconsanguineous parents. He had been born at term with no perinatal complications. He had achieved neck holding and social smile. The family history was not significant.

On examination the child had an axillary temperature of 105°F. He had sparse, hypopigmented, and fuzzy hair, sparse eyebrows, periorbital hyperpigmentation, depressed nasal bridge, and dry skin. Neurological examination revealed altered sensorium, reduced tone in all 4 limbs, and brisk deep tendon reflexes. There were no signs of meningeal irritation. Systemic examination was unremarkable. The sepsis screen and blood cultures were negative. Cerebrospinal fluid examination revealed no abnormalities. Skin biopsy from the hypothenar palmar skin showed complete absence of sweat glands, confirming the diagnosis of hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed signal alteration with restricted diffusion in the splenium of corpus callosum, cerebral peduncles, and cerebellar dentate nuclei (Figures 1 -3).

caption.p: Axial T2 weighted magnetic resonance images of the brain show hyperintense signal changes in the bilateral dentate nuclei (arrows in A) and in bilateral cerebral peduncles (arrows in B).

Axial diffusion weighted magnetic resonance images of the brain demonstrating restricted diffusion in the dentate nuclei (arrows in A), midbrain peduncles (arrows in B), and also in the splenium of corpus callosum (arrow in C). The corresponding areas are hypointense on apparent diffusion coefficient map images in Figure 3.

Apparent diffusion coefficient maps showing hypointense areas suggestive of restrictive diffusion in the dentate nuclei (arrows in A), midbrain peduncles (arrows in B), and also in the splenium of corpus callosum (arrow in C).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia is an inherited disorder affecting tissues derived from ectodermal structures such as hair shaft, nail abnormalities, and sweat glands. Intermittent hyperpyrexia and heat stroke may occur because of decreased sweating. The mortality rate can be as high as 30% during these episodes. Recurrent high fever can also lead to seizures as in our patient.

Brain malformations have been rarely reported in association with hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia. Widely dilated perivascular spaces, dysmyelination, and partial hypoplasia of the cerebellum have been reported. 1, 2 There are very few reports of magnetic resonance imaging findings in heat stroke. Lee et al described a case of heat stroke in an adult with restricted diffusion in the cerebellar dentate nuclei and splenium, suggestive of cytotoxic edema. 3 Our patient also had similar findings. Restricted diffusion in the midbain, cerebellum, and thalami has also been described. 4 Other findings that have been described with heat stroke in ectodermal dysplasia include restricted diffusion in bilateral temporo-occipital lobes. 5 The differential disgnosis of the neuroimaging findings in our case include metronidazole-induced toxicity 6 and methyl bromide toxicity. 7
